Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Value-Added Products from Decommissioned Composite Material Wind Turbine Blades
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to explore translation of mass-market architectural, engineering and construction (AEC) products produced from repurposed Fiber Reinforced Polymer (FRP) composite wind turbine blades. FRP wind turbine blades are made from high quality composite materials but do not recycle into new FRP materials. As a result, obsolete blades are currently disposed in a landfill or incinerated. These disposal methods are problematic from an economic, environmental, and social perspective. Thousands of first-generation wind turbines are currently being decommissioned and the blades stockpiled for want of alternative disposal solutions. Using the proposed technology, the wind blades will be converted to electrical power transmission structures and other large-scale civil infrastructure products using proprietary software and hardware developed by the research. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of algorithms and software for wind blade modeling and analysis and in methods for wind blade re-use. The algorithms create geometric and structural models of wind turbine blades automatically from point clouds built from laser scans or photographs. The algorithms also create engineering property data required for structural analysis of the re-use structures under civil engineering loading conditions, which are quite different from the aerodynamic loading for which the wind blades were originally designed. The software includes methods for the automated production of digital models of the wind blades, for visualization, product design, structural design and analysis, and fabrication and construction, all starting from the proprietary processing of digitized scans of the blades using LIDAR or photogrammetry. In addition, new methods and hardware may facilitate structural re-use applications of the wind blades in large-scale civil infrastructure applications. Further research provides the ability to predict the remaining life in the composite materials within the decommissioned wind turbine blades and safe stress limits for use in various re-use applications.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I-Corps Award 2042029
I-Corps: Value-Added Products from Decommissioned Composite Material Wind Turbine Blades

The major goal of NSF I-Corps project 2042029 is to develop mass-market architectural, engineering and construction (AEC) products produced from re-purposed Fiber Reinforced Polymer (FRP) composite wind turbine blades. The research team at Georgia Tech is part of a network of universities including partners in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland collaborating through the Re-Wind Network. More information on the network can be found here: www.re-wind.info.

Fiber reinforced polymer wind turbine blades are made from high quality composite materials that do not recycle into new FRP materials. As a result, obsolete blades are currently landfilled or incinerated. These disposal methods are problematic from an economic, environmental, and social perspective. Through the businesses created by this I-Corps project, the wind blades will be converted to electrical power transmission structures and other large-scale civil infrastructure products using proprietary software and hardware technologies developed by the research team. The commercial enterprise resulting from this project will accrue value from a two-sided market with revenues coming from the wind farms decommissioning the wind turbine blades, and the clients who receive products created from the wind turbine blades.

The original I-Corps proposal identified four models for our business, with the differences related to how we generate revenue, either from enabling the structural re-purposing of wind turbine blades with our intellectual property and capabilities, or by explicitly taking ownership of the decommissioned wind blades and then remanufacturing them into value-added products (see Figure 1). These models were referred to as the "consulting" and "vendor" model respectively. Two additional models, the "franchise" and "brokerage" models fell somewhere between these two poles. In our initial interaction with our I-Corps mentors at Georgia Tech, we were encouraged to focus on the vendor model, the most conventional means of making and selling a product. The I-Corps focus was to be on the details of the products and their inherent value, not the means of bringing those products to market.

The I-Corps team completed the national I-Corps program in 2020. Members included Angie Nagle (EL), Chloe Kiernicki (co-EL), Russell Gentry (PI/TL) and James Marlow (IM).  Yulizza Henao-Barragan, joined the project team in September 2020 and shadowed the I-Corps team. The team continued their customer discovery through 2022 with follow-on funding granted by the Georgia Tech CreateX program.

The I-Corps team developed two pieces of intellectual property going into I-Corps, (1) US Patent Application 17/632,993: "Systems and Methods for Repurposing Retired Wind Turbines as Electric Utility Line Poles" and (2) US Patent Application 17/434,588, "Systems and Methods for Predicting the Geometry and Internal Structure of Turbine Blades".  In addition, the team conceptualized a number of additional re-use applications that were in the concept phase, but lacking detailed design, prototyping and intellectual property protection. The MIT I-Corps node suggested that our I-Corps team focus on one product, and we selected the BladePole, a high voltage electrical transmission pole constructed from a 30 to 50 meter decommissioned wind blade (Figure 2).

We received tremendous enthusiasm and support from one side of our postulated two-sided market, that is, the wind energy sector, which is keen to have cost-effective, value-added, sustainable, non-polluting, and socially-acceptable ways to decommission wind turbines and ensure the circularity of the materials used in wind energy systems. The second side of our two-sided markets were the diverse group of industries and customers that will receive second-life products and services from the decommissioned wind turbine blades. We found enthusiasm and open-mindedness to be uneven across this diverse group. In some cases, such as with our collaborators in Cork, Ireland, those receiving the Re-Wind products were quite eager -- making our value proposition clear. In other cases the customers were satisfied with their existing product choices, and our value proposition of lower costs and sustainability were not sufficient to overcome the real and perceived risks associated with the use of a structural product made from re-purposed materials.

The Re-Wind team at Georgia Tech continues to focus on structural re-use as we develop and demonstrate additional wind blade re-purposing concepts with our wind energy and civil infrastructure stakeholders. Our work provides a tangible blueprint for the broad challenge of reducing construction demolition waste -- especially to those working to find re-use applications for the vast number of structural components and materials (e.g., portland cement concrete, steel, wood) that are landfilled each year. 

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2023
Modified by: Russell T Gentry
